text: <extra_id_0> Foxp3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> Suppresses NF-kappaB Dependent Transcriptional Activation

To ascertain the molecular mechanisms by which <extra_id_0> Foxp3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> functions to promote the regulatory function of <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + <extra_id_0> CD25 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> hi T cells , we first confirmed the function of <extra_id_0> Foxp3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> as a repressor of activation of NF-kappaB , previously implicated as a target of other forkhead / winged-helix family transcription factors ( e.g . , <extra_id_0> Foxj1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> Foxo3a <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) [ 19 , 20 ] .
We analyzed the effect of <extra_id_0> Foxp3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> overexpression on NF-kappaB activation in HEK 293T cells in dose - response and time course analyses .

Transfection of HEK 293T cells with an NF-kappaB <extra_id_0> luciferase <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> reporter vector in the presence or absence of increasing concentrations of a <extra_id_0> Foxp3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> expression vector or a control vector ( enhanced <extra_id_0> green fluorescent protein <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> [ EGFP ] ) was performed , and cells were harvested after 24 h to assay for <extra_id_0> luciferase <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> activity and <extra_id_0> Foxp3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> mRNA expression .

text: Results indicated that as the concentration of <extra_id_0> Foxp3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> transfected into cells increases ( from 50 to 2 , 400 ng ) , the level of NF-kappaB activation decreases proportionally ( Figure 1A ) .

text: <extra_id_0> Foxp3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> mRNA was also assayed to monitor activity of the <extra_id_0> Foxp3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> expression vector ( Figure 1B ) .

Since NF-kappaB activation was partially affected by transfection of high concentrations of the control vector , we determined the fold inhibition of NF-kappaB activation by <extra_id_0> Foxp3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> compared to the control vector at each concentration ( Figure 1A ) .
Fold inhibition of NF-kappaB activation was directly proportional to the level of <extra_id_0> Foxp3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> mRNA expression detected by real-time RT-PCR .

To determine the level of <extra_id_0> Foxp3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - mediated suppression of NF-kappaB activation over time , HEK 293T cells were transfected with an NF-kappaB <extra_id_0> luciferase <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> reporter vector and an expression vector encoding <extra_id_0> Foxp3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> or EGFP ( control vector ) and harvested over 4 d .
As shown in Figure 1C , NF-kappaB activation was suppressed by overexpression of <extra_id_0> Foxp3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> at all time points .

Extending these results from established , in vitro HEK cell lines to primary human lymphocytes , overexpression of <extra_id_0> Foxp3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in purified <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + T cells from three healthy donors also down-regulated the steady-state level of NF-kappaB activation ( Figure 1D ) .

These results recapitulate those from Bettelli and colleagues [ 15 ] demonstrating that <extra_id_0> Foxp3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> functions , in part , to block NF-kappaB - dependent transcription in human cell lines as well as in primary human <extra_id_0> CD4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> + T cells .
